title-group.article-title: The Role of Responsible Gambling Strategy in Forming Behavioral Intention
title-group.subtitle: An Application of a Model of Goal-Directed Behavior

author-notes.corresp: Choong-Ki Lee, College of Hotel & Tourism Management, Kyung Hee University, 1 Hoegi-dong, Dongdaemun-gu, Seoul 130-701 Korea Email: cklee@khu.ac.kr

abstract.p: By examining the perception of a responsible gambling strategy, this study developed an extended model of goal-directed behavior (EMGB) with respect to the behavioral intentions of casino visitors. The results of the EMGB, which uses structural equation modeling, indicate that desire had the strongest relationship with casino visitors’ intention to gamble, followed by positive anticipated emotion, perceived behavioral control, perceptions of a responsible gambling strategy, negative anticipated emotion, and attitude. The perception of a responsible gambling strategy was also a significant predictor of both desire and behavioral intention, as casino visitors had positive perceptions of casinos that implemented responsible gambling strategies. Casino managers should consider a responsible gambling strategy as an important long-term business activity to increase casino visitor’s intention to gamble.

body.p: Although gambling is still controversial in many countries, the gambling industry is expanding at a rapid pace (Lee et al. 2006). Cook (1992) stated that casino gambling has transformed into a mainstream activity, which many people see as fundamentally similar to many other recreational activities. Consistent with this change in the casino industry, it is essential that casino visitors be assured of appropriate safeguards, through responsible gambling strategies, to protect them from the harm of casino gambling (Monaghan 2009). Recognizing the need for the casino industry to have a code of ethics, many casino managers and operators now seek to incorporate casino visitors’ emerging requests about responsible gambling into their marketing strategies. Specifically, casino managers are interested in managing their casino operations in a socially acceptable manner and in implementing socially sound practices. Altering their casino operations to be sustainable (i.e., reducing negative impacts from casino gambling) is becoming a necessity for attaining noticeable improvements in their industry competitiveness.

Since the late 1980s, research on casino gambling has flourished because of the widespread legalization of casino gambling in the United States (Oh and Hsu 2001). Most studies have focused on the economic and social impacts of casinos in specific locales (Carmichael, Peppard, and Boudreau 1996; Chadbourne, Walker, and Wolfe 1997; Cozzetto 1995; Giacopassi and Stitt 1993; Long, Clark, and Liston 1994; Stephenson 1996; Stokowski 1996). However, research on understanding casino visitors’ behavioral intentions, using a theoretical framework, has been neglected (Oh and Hsu 2001). One appropriate way of addressing this shortcoming and expanding the body of knowledge in casino-related studies is to employ a sound theoretical framework. Understanding the reasoning process of casino gamblers is important to sustaining rapid growth in the casino industry and to developing effective marketing strategies. Employing a new theoretical framework in the casino context can provide a clear understanding of the complicated process by which casino gamblers form their behavioral intentions.

Although it is not an easy task to understand the complex decision-making processes of tourists, Lam and Hsu (2004, 2006) asserted that intention to visit a tourist destination is a significant clue to understanding their decision-making processes. Tourists form behavioral intention through their own thinking processes, and the derived behavioral intention plays an essential role in leading actual visiting behavior. In this regard, the model of goal-directed behavior (MGB) could be valuable as a new theoretical framework for explaining the behavioral intention of casino visitors. The MGB, first proposed by Perugini and Bagozzi (2001), is an alternative approach to the theory of planned behavior (TPB). The MGB has recently received attention as a means to understand a variety of human behaviors, such as brand-related behavior, drinking alcohol, digital piracy, and information search (Bagozzi and Dholakia 2006; Prestwich, Perugini, and Hurling 2008; Taylor 2007; Taylor, Ishida, and Wallace 2009) because of its superior predictive ability. In spite of the usefulness of the MGB, this model has not been tested or applied in the context of casinos.

Therefore, the purpose of this study is to understand casino visitors’ behavioral intentions using an extended MGB that adds the new construct of the perception of a responsible gambling strategy to an original MGB. Although studies have explored individual behavioral intention to gamble (Cummings and Corney 1987; Moore and Ohtsuka 1999; Oh and Hsu 2001; Walker, Courneya, and Deng 2006; Wood and Griffiths 2004), earlier studies were limited to an examination of gambling behaviors without considering the effect of motivation and emotion (Bagozzi, Dholakia, and Pearo 2007). Because gambling behaviors reflect a high expectation to win money (Platz and Millar 2001), the gambling behavior of casino visitors is likely to result mainly from habitual, motivational, and emotional factors, including cognitive factors in the TPB. Therefore, a more advanced model, like the MGB, is necessary to consider these various factors to help researchers and managers better understand the gambling behavior of casino visitors.

sec.title: Responsible Gambling Strategy
sec.p: Casinos have long been controversial in many countries. While the casino is a recreational activity for many people, for some people it sometimes leads to serious negative consequences, including financial and personal losses (Lee et al. 2009). In other words, casinos have very distinctive characteristics, generating both positive and negative outcomes. For the sustainable development of the casino industry, many local governments and casino companies have tried to reduce the risk and severity of adverse consequences associated with casinos through various activities (Hing 2003). For example, many casino companies in Las Vegas have attempted to change their casino operation styles from gambling-only casinos to integrated resort casinos targeting the general public. Integrated resort casinos increasingly provide visitors with a variety of entertainment options, including theme parks, a variety of gambling options, and bustling convention centers. A Gaming Control Board or the local government has the authority to approve licenses, regulate policies, and supervise casino operations. Casino operators should keep guidelines set by the Gaming Control Board to minimize adverse impacts, such as problem gambling. The Alberta Health Services (the former Alberta Alcohol Drug Abuse Commission) in Canada provides counseling, day treatment, and residential treatment, including short-term and long-term treatments for problem gamblers (Alberta Health Services 2011). The Alberta Health Services also develops education and promotion programs aimed at the prevention of problem gambling.

One recently created code of ethics in the world’s casino industry is the formation of a responsible gambling strategy, which seeks to minimize the harmful effects associated with gambling for both the customers and the community (Hing 2003). In other words, responsible gambling strategy is an action or policy taken by casino operators to minimize the harmful effects of gambling on casino visitors and maximize the benefits of gambling for the local community (Monaghan 2009). Casino managers worldwide have begun to embrace this approach as a strategy for long-term sustainable development. With respect to the casino operators’ responsible gambling strategies, it is possible for casino visitors to perceive a casino operator’s responsible gambling strategy using their knowledge, information, and experiences (following the definition of perception as an individual’s cognitive process with respect to his or her response to objects, behaviors, and events that are filtered through the person’s knowledge, information, and experiences; J. R. Anderson 2004; Oliver 1997). As casino visitors become aware of the casino’s responsible gambling strategy, they are likely to form and change their attitudes, interests, and opinions regarding the casino in question. Some scholars have stated that a definite level of perception of objects, behaviors, and events is related to an individual’s decision-making process regarding a specific behavior (Oliver 1993, 1997; Oliver and Swan 1989). However, despite the relationship that may exist between the perception of a responsible gambling strategy and behavioral variables, no study has yet attempted to explore their relationship because previous studies have been exploratory in nature, without specific theoretical frameworks. In other words, no empirical research has been conducted to examine whether such strategy influences the casino visitors’ intention-formation process. Thus, this study explores the effect of responsible gambling strategy on casino visitors’ behavioral intentions.

sec.title: MGB and Extended MGB
sec.p: Perugini and Bagozzi (2001) proposed the MGB to address the limitations of the TPB. In the MGB, although all original antecedents (attitude, subjective norm, and perceived behavioral control) of the TPB are included, the role of each is redefined. In other words, attitude, subjective norm, and perceived behavioral control affect behavioral intention indirectly in the MGB through desire, while these variables influence behavioral intention directly in the TPB. Perugini and Bagozzi (2001) also claimed that to better understand human behavior, motivational and affective processes and past behavior should be included in the model. Their approach was based on three ideas. First, desire can be a critical factor in explaining a person’s decision formation (Perugini and Bagozzi 2001). Second, anticipated affective reactions to a specific behavior can be imperative variables in decision-making processes (Conner and Armitage 1998). Van der Pligt and De Vries (1998) also stated that anticipated affective reactions to the performance of a behavior might be an important determinant of intention. Third, past behavior or habit can be a significant determinant of human decisions or behavior (Bentler and Speckart 1981; Ouellette and Wood 1998). Therefore, the MGB incorporated desire, positive and negative anticipated emotions, and past behaviors in addition to the original variables of the TPB. Because of its superior predictive ability against the TPB, the MGB has recently been used to explain a variety of human behaviors, including brand-related behavior (Bagozzi and Dholakia 2006), drinking alcohol (Prestwich, Perugini, and Hurling 2008), drinking soft drinks (Richetin et al. 2008), digital piracy (Taylor, Ishida, and Wallace 2009), fruit intake (Prestwich, Perugini, and Hurling 2008), and information search (Taylor 2007).

Some researchers (Ajzen 1991; Oh and Hsu 2001) have emphasized the necessity of revising existing sociopsychological theories to include new constructs that are considered critical in a certain context or that alter existing paths among latent variables. Perugini and Bagozzi (2001) described this process as the broadening and deepening of a theory, which can enhance the predictive power of specific human behaviors in specific contexts by providing a better understanding of the theoretical mechanism of sociopsychological theories.

In this regard, the current study proposes a model that expands the MGB by incorporating a new construct, perceptions of responsible gambling strategy, which is deemed an important construct in the casino visitors’ intention-formation process (Blaszczynski, Ladouceur, and Shaffer 2004; Hing 2003; Monaghan 2009).

sec.title: Relationships among attitude, subjective norm, perceived behavioral control, desire, and intention
sec.p: In the MGB, the following terms are used: Attitude is redefined as “a psychological tendency that is expressed by evaluating a particular entity with some degree of favor or disfavor” (Eagly and Chaiken 1993, p. 1); subjective norm refers to the perceived social pressure to perform a specific behavior (Perugini and Bagozzi 2001); and perceived behavioral control refers to an individual’s confidence in or ability to execute a specific behavior (Ajzen 1991). Researchers agree that an individual’s attitude and subjective norm have a significant influence on desire and that these variables do not directly affect his or her intention to perform a behavior. However, they affect intention indirectly through desire in the MGB (Perugini and Bagozzi 2001; Prestwich, Perugini, and Hurling 2008; Taylor 2007). In addition, previous studies about the MGB verified that perceived behavioral control significantly affects an individual’s desire and both directly and indirectly reinforces his or her intentions (Carrus, Passafaro, and Bonnes 2008; Perugini and Bagozzi 2001; Prestwich, Perugini, and Hurling 2008).

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1 (H1): Attitude has a positive effect on desire.
Hypothesis 2 (H2): Subjective norm has a positive effect on desire.
Hypothesis 3 (H3): Perceived behavioral control has a positive effect on desire.
Hypothesis 4 (H4): Perceived behavioral control has a positive effect on behavioral intention.

sec.title: Relationship between anticipated emotions and desire
sec.p: In a situation of uncertainty, people may have forward-looking emotions toward future behaviors. Gleicher et al. (1995) identified these anticipated counterfactuals as prefactuals, which can affect both intention and behavior. In the MGB, anticipated emotions, along with the original variables of the TPB, are assumed to predict desire in that these emotions lead to the dynamic self-regulatory process implied by the appraisal of success or failure (Carver and Scheier 1998). Regarding the relationship between anticipated emotion and desire, many researchers have found that the anticipated emotion for a target behavior exerts a significant influence on the individual’s desire-related target behavior (Richetin et al. 2008; Taylor, Ishida, and Wallace 2009).

list-item.p: Hypothesis 5 (H5): Positive anticipated emotion has a positive effect on desire.
Hypothesis 6 (H6): Negative anticipated emotion has a positive effect on desire.

sec.title: Relationships among past behavior, desire, and intention
sec.p: Although the original model of TPB does not consider the influence of past behavior, several attitude and behavior studies have found that past behavior has an effect on individual intention (Bagozzi and Warshaw 1992; Perugini and Bagozzi 2001; Taylor, Ishida, and Wallace 2009). These researchers agree that if an individual performs a particular behavior frequently and habitually, such behavior will influence the individual’s desire and behavioral intentions.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 7 (H7): The frequency of past behavior has a positive effect on desire.
Hypothesis 8 (H8): The frequency of past behavior has a positive effect on behavioral intention.

sec.title: Relationship between desire and intention
sec.p: Bagozzi (1992) claims that the key factor omitted in the TPB is desire, a motivation-based variable linked to behavioral intention. According to Bagozzi (1992), desire is a proximal cause of intention, whereas other variables in the MGB are regarded as distal causes in which influence is completely mediated by desire. In the MGB, attitudes are typically regarded as evaluative appraisals (Perugini and Bagozzi 2001). If these evaluations are strong enough, attitudes will influence a person’s intention to enact or not enact a specific behavior. However, evaluative appraisals cannot activate intention without desire because they do not usually entail motivational commitment. The inclusion of desire makes up the TPB by reinterpreting the role of the original variables in the TPB (Perugini and Bagozzi 2001; Taylor, Ishida, and Wallace 2009).

list-item.p: Hypothesis 9 (H9): Desire has a positive effect on behavioral intention.

sec.title: Relationships among the perception of responsible gambling strategy, desire, and intention
sec.p: Various approaches have been conducted by scholars to assess gamblers’ awareness, perceived adequacy, and perceived effectiveness with regard to responsible gambling strategies (Blaszczynski, Ladouceur, and Shaffer 2004; Hing 2003; Monaghan 2009). The possible relationships among the perception of a responsible gambling strategy, desire, and intention are supported by some scholars in the field of marketing who have used similar terms for analyzing corporate social responsibility. Corporate social responsibility is conceptually similar to responsible gambling in that corporate social responsibility is defined by managerial activities that, based on the concept of sustainable development, protect consumers and contribute to the development of the community (Murray and Vogel 1997; Turban and Greening 1997).

Positive corporate images, implemented by corporate social responsibility strategies, are likely to directly affect customer attitudes and behaviors (Brown and Dacin 1997; Wansink 1989). The positive relationships among corporate social responsibility, consumer attitudes (Berens, Riel, and Bruggen 2005; Lee and Shin 2010; Ross, Patterson, and Stutts 1992), and purchasing intentions (Klein and Dawar 2004; Sen and Bhattacharya 2001) have been demonstrated in past studies. In this respect, this study posits that the perception of a responsible gambling strategy has either a direct or an indirect positive effect on a casino visitor’s desire and intention to gamble, as the following hypotheses suggest:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 10 (H10): The perception of a responsible gambling strategy has a positive effect on desire.
Hypothesis 11 (H11): The perception of a responsible gambling strategy has a positive effect on behavioral intention.

sec.title: Construct Measurement
sec.p: All constructs in this study, except past behavior, are measured with multiple items because a set of measures tends to be more reliable and valid than any single measure (Churchill 1979). Multiple indicators to measure theoretical constructs can also enhance validity, covering various facets of the construct (Kline 2005). A preliminary list of measurement items was generated after an extensive review of the literature pertaining to the behavior of tourists, casino gambling, and the theories of human behavior (Ajzen 1985, 1991; Ajzen and Madden 1986; Bagozzi, Baumgartner, and Pieters 1998; Bentler and Speckart 1981; Carrus, Passafaro, and Bonnes 2008; Lam and Hsu 2004, 2006; Oh and Hsu 2001; Perugini and Bagozzi 2001, 2004; Young and Wohl 2009).

In particular, measurement items associated with a responsible gambling strategy were generated from the current responsible gambling policy of the Kangwon Land Casino in South Korea, the research site of this study. Next, tourism scholars and casino managers were asked to clarify the generated items and comment on whether or not these items were appropriate for evaluating casino visitors’ behaviors. Also, all items were pretested with casino managers and dealers and graduate students. Through these processes a final questionnaire was developed and refined (all measurement items are in Table 3).

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: Questionnaires were administered at a temporary booth near the main exit of the Kangwon Land Casino, which is the only casino for domestic Korean people in South Korea. The Problem Gambling and Prevention Center for Kangwon Land Casino allowed researchers to interact with gamblers. This research team was given an opportunity that is exceedingly rare in the literature on gambling studies—that is, an opportunity to interview casino gamblers on-site in a live gambling situation. To collect a more representative sample of casino gamblers, and because gamblers’ profiles were likely to be different depending on weekdays and weekends, the survey was conducted with on-site casino gamblers on both weekdays and weekends in the third week of December 2009. Gamblers voluntarily came to the survey booth, where field researchers outlined the purpose of the research project and invited these gamblers to participate in the survey. On approval, a self-administered questionnaire was presented to each respondent.

The questionnaires were completed in the presence of the field researchers, allowing for rigorous monitoring of the data collection process. A small gift of chocolate was provided to those who completed the survey questionnaire. A total of 515 questionnaires were gathered from the survey, but after a thorough examination, 60 questionnaires were eliminated from the analysis because of missing and patterned data. Finally, 455 questionnaires were coded and used for analysis.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: Collected data were analyzed with structural equation modeling (SEM) using SPSS (SPSS 2001) and EQS (Bentler and Wu 1995). As a first step, an exploratory factor analysis was executed to identify the structure of factors and systematically purify measured indicators of constructs. As a second step, a two-step approach was employed to analyze the data (Anderson and Gerbing 1988), in which a measurement model for the original MGB variables was estimated using confirmatory factor analysis, and then structural relationships among original MGB variables were estimated. Once an extended model of goal-directed behavior (EMGB) was developed by including the new construct of perception of a responsible gambling strategy, EMGB was compared to the original MGB to determine whether or not EMGB was the best model for understanding casino visitors’ intention formation when considering the perception of a responsible gambling strategy.

sec.title: Demographic Characteristics of Respondents
sec.p: Table 1 presents demographic characteristics of the respondents. The proportion of male respondents (69.5%) was higher than that of female respondents (30.5%). The majority of respondents were ages 30–39 (31.6%) and ages 40–49 (30.5%). University-level graduates or higher were predominant, representing 53.6% of the respondents. Many of the respondents considered themselves to be middle-income earners (2 million to 3.9 million Korean won per month, where US$1 is equivalent to 1,145 Korean won; 47.2%) and middle- to high-income earners (over 4 million won; 26.9%). Married people were dominant (65.7%).

sec.title: Testing for Measurement and Structural Models, Reliability, and Validity
sec.p: For estimating SEM, maximum likelihood estimation is generally used under the assumption of multivariate normality for collected data (Byrne 2006). To confirm whether or not the data in the study violated the assumption of multivariate normality, Mardia’s standardized coefficient was employed. Because Mardia’s standardized coefficient for the measurement model (42.44) was greater than the criterion of 5, it was considered that the data in the current study were multivariate, non-normally distributed (Byrne 2006). Therefore, the robust maximum likelihood method was used to estimate structural equation modeling in the study. This method, based on Satorra-Bentler (S-B) chi-square, can provide more robust and valid chi-square values, standard errors, and other fit indices when the data violate the multivariate normality assumption (Byrne 1994, 2006; Bentler and Wu 1995). As shown in Table 2, the proposed measurement and structural models were found to fit the data well, with a good fit to the data for the measurement model (normed fit index [NFI] = .929, non-normed fit index [NNFI] = .954, comparative fit index [CFI] = .961, root mean square error of approximation [RMSEA] = .046) and structural model (NFI = .920, NNFI = .946, CFI = .954, RMSEA = .053).

fn.p: NFI = normed fit index; NNFI = non-normed fit index; CFI = comparative fit index; RMSEA = root mean square error of approximation. Suggested values are based on Hair et al. (2006) and Bearden, Sharma, and Teel (1982).

sec.p: As shown in Table 3, all factor loadings were greater than the minimum criterion of .5, with significantly associated t-values, supporting the convergent validity of the measurement model (Anderson and Gerbing 1988). Also, reliability and construct validity for the measurement model were examined in Table 4. In terms of reliability, each construct had sufficient reliability because the values of Cronbach’s alpha ranged from .851 to .949, exceeding the suggested minimum criterion of .7 (Nunnally 1978).

sec.p: Convergent and discriminant validity statistics are presented in Table 4. All average variance extracted (AVE) and composite reliability (CR) values for the multi-item scales were greater than the minimum criteria of .5 and .7, respectively (Hair et al. 2006). The results indicate a sufficient level of convergent validity for the measurement model. To check discriminant validity of the constructs, three methods were used in the study. The first method using AVE did not confirm discriminant validity, as the highest squared correlation between desire and behavioral intention (.666) was greater than the AVE for corresponding interconstructs (desire = .594, behavioral intention = .628; Fornell and Larcker 1981). However, the other two methods, which used confidence intervals and constrained models, supported the discriminant validity levels. Specifically, the confidence interval of the correlation between desire and behavioral intention (.980, .652), plus or minus two standard errors of correlation between the constructs, did not include the criterion of 1.0, based on a confidence interval method (Anderson and Gerbing 1992). Discriminant validity using a constrained model was also confirmed because the S-B chi-square difference test statistic for the relationship between desire and behavioral intention (20.53) exceeded the criterion of 3.84 (p < .001; Bagozzi and Phillips 1982; Steenkamp and Trijp 1991).

sec.title: Comparison of MGB and EMGB
sec.p: The two competing models, MGB and EMGB, were compared using the explanatory power of each model (Table 5). When compared to the MGB, the EMGB improved R2 from .760 to .767 by including the perception of a responsible gambling strategy. The S-B chi-square difference test between MGB and EMGB indicated that there was a significant difference between the two models, Δ S-B χ2(110) = 211.14, p < .001. Thus, the EMGB did better job of accounting for the variance in the explanations of behavioral intentions when compared to the MGB. The results showed that the EMGB, which added the perception of a responsible gambling strategy as a new construct to the original MGB, performed slightly better than the MGB at explaining behavioral intentions to gamble in casinos.

sec.title: Tests of Hypotheses
sec.p: EMGB as a final research model was developed by adding the perception of a responsible gambling strategy to the MGB. Figure 1 represents the results of the EMGB. Five predictor variables, positive anticipated emotion (βPAE→DE = .375, t = 5.140, p < .01), negative anticipated emotion (βNAE→DE = .267, t = 5.333, p <.01), attitude (βAT→DE = .232, t = 3.613, p < .01), perception of a responsible gambling strategy (βPRGS→DE = .136, t = 2.999, p < .01), and frequency of past behavior (βFPB→DE = .099, t = 2.514, p < .05), were positively associated with desire to gamble in casinos, supporting H1, H5, H6, H7, and H10. However, subjective norm (βSN→DE = .051, t = 1.302, ns; not significant) and perceived behavioral control (βPBC→DE = −.023, t = −.380, ns) were not statistically significant for predicting desire to gamble, rejecting H2 and H3. Other hypotheses related to behavioral intention were also tested. As expected, the relationships among desire, perceived behavioral control, the perception of a responsible gambling strategy, and behavioral intention were positive and significant (βDE→BI = .725, t = 11.485, p < .01; βPBC→BI = .232, t = 4.131, p < .01; βPRGS→BI = .097, t = 2.132, p < .05), supporting H9, H4, and H11. However, the frequency of past behavior was not statistically significant for predicting behavioral intention to gamble (βFOP→DE = .004, t = .115, ns), rejecting H8.

caption.p: Results of extended model of goal-directed behavior

sec.p: Overall, five constructs (positive anticipated emotion, negative anticipated emotion, attitude, the perception of a responsible gambling strategy, and the frequency of past behavior) played an essential role in explaining the formation of casino visitors’ desire to gamble, and three constructs (desire, perceived behavioral control, and the perception of a responsible gambling strategy) performed an important role in predicting visitors’ behavioral intention to gamble. It is interesting to note that the perception of a responsible gambling strategy was also a significant predictor of both desire and behavioral intention. This finding indicates that a responsible gambling strategy is closely related to the casino visitor’s gambling behavior.

The total effect of the study’s variables on intention was examined. As shown in Table 6, desire was found to be the most important factor, with the largest total impact (.725) on behavioral intention, followed by positive anticipated emotion (.272), perceived behavioral control (.215), the perception of a responsible gambling strategy (.196), negative anticipated emotion (.194), and attitude (.168).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The perception of a responsible gambling strategy is likely to affect the casino industry positively. Little research has examined how it influences casino visitors’ intention-formation process. This study aimed to examine the effect of the perception of a responsible gambling strategy on the casino visitor’s intention to gamble at a casino by developing the EMGB. The perception of a responsible gambling strategy had a positive effect on both desire and behavioral intention and increased the variance of the EMGB. This finding supports the predictive validity of perception of a responsible gambling strategy.

Desire as a sufficient impetus for intention formation was the most important construct among antecedent constructs in the EMGB. In the model, the more important determinants of desire were emotional factors, specifically positive anticipated emotions. The importance of emotional factors to casino visitors might explain why they are more likely to gamble because of emotional rather than other cognitive factors. This might be attributable to the fact that gambling behaviors are likely to be motivated by high expectations of making money, which are related to emotional decision making but not rational decision making (Lee et al. 2006; Neighbors et al. 2002; Platz and Millar 2001). This finding would not have been discovered if we had employed only the TPB.

It is also noteworthy in this study that there were no unique cause–effect relationships among subjective norm, perceived behavioral control, and desire, but attitude was a significant predictor for desire among the original variables of TPB. Although Lam and Hsu (2004) stated that Asians tend to rate self-monitoring highly and struggle with undertaking a specific behavior because of other people’s attention and opinions for that behavior, the results of this study did not support that conclusion (Han, Hsu, and Sheu 2010; Lam and Hsu 2004; Sparks and Pan 2009). This insignificant relationship between the subjective norm and desire might be attributable to the characteristics of the study sample. Casino games are not popular leisure activities, and some people have negative perceptions of casino gambling in Korea. This means that casino visitors have unique characteristics compared to other people who enjoy other leisure activities, and they are not likely to use others’ opinions as sources of information when making the decision to gamble. In addition, the insignificant relationship between perceived behavioral control and desire indicates that people usually do not consider their resources or opportunities to gamble at the stage of forming a desire, but they do consider those things at the stage of forming an intention.

The current study using EMGB as a new theoretical framework has both theoretical and practical implications. First, the EMGB accounted for more variance in behavioral intention than the MGB did, which indicates slightly better predictive validity for the EMGB. This finding is consistent with Ajzen’s (1991) assertion that scholars should consider additional factors and relationships among latent variables to explain a substantial proportion of the total variance in intention. A simultaneous examination of the EMGB not only contributes to enhancing understanding of the intricate mechanism that forms the behavioral intention to gamble but also avoids potential misspecifications that may include unimportant variables or omit important variables in the model. Second, it was found that positive anticipated emotion, negative anticipated emotion, attitude, the perception of a responsible gambling strategy, and the frequency of past behavior were important factors when determining desire. Desire, perceived behavioral control, and the perception of a responsible gambling strategy were found to be significant factors in affecting behavioral intention. Consistent with previous studies of MGB (e.g., Bagozzi and Dholakia 2006; Carrus, Passafaro, and Bonnes 2008; Taylor 2007), the results of the current study demonstrate that three additional factors (desire, anticipated emotions, and past behavior) largely enhanced the predictive power of a specific human behavior in the context of casino gambling. Although all antecedent variables in the EMGB cannot make a considerable contribution to behavioral intention to gamble, this is not problematic because the relative importance of individual antecedent variables in the model may differ based on given contexts (Sparks and Pan 2009).

Third, according to previous research, which proposed possible relationships among perceptions of a responsible gambling strategy, desire, and intention, the perception of a responsible gambling strategy was a significant predictor to determine desire and behavioral intention to gamble in casinos. The finding suggests that the perception of a responsible gambling strategy increased desire and behavioral intention to gamble, as casino visitors had a positive image of casino companies that implemented responsible gambling strategies.

Therefore, casino operators may need to promote responsible gambling strategies because they have a positive effect on desire and behavioral intention. Kangwon Land Casino in Korea needs to continue to provide counseling services for potential problem gamblers at the Problem Gambling and Prevention Center. It is also a good responsible strategy that Kangwon Land Casino restricted by law the residents of the four surrounding communities from visiting the casino more than once a month because the residents are susceptible to problem gambling. Restrictions on general domestic Korean visitors to Kangwon Land Casino to a maximum of 15 times a month should be continuously implemented to minimize adverse impacts of casinos, such as problem gambling. Kangwon Land’s responsible gambling strategy of closing for a few hours a day, thus not being a 24-hour casino, is also effectively minimizing social costs. This responsible gambling strategy helps players not get addicted to casino gambling all day long.

Lee et al. (2006) studied casino market segmentation, recommending that the light and multipurpose gambling seekers were responsible gambling segments. Thus, casino operators may need to attract the market segments that enjoy casino gambling as a social and leisure activity. Casino operators may need to encourage family visitors to buy tour packages for surrounding tourist sites by linking casino gambling with local tourism attractions (e.g., local cultural events, museums, and themed villages) as part of their implementation of a responsible gambling strategy. These implications are associated with international trends, in which the casino industry is building integrated resorts, such as those in Las Vegas and Singapore. Casinos in Las Vegas provide more leisure and recreational activities, such as shows, restaurants, and entertainment, to attract pleasure and family tourists. The findings of this study suggest that these types of casino visitors would be more desirable for casino businesses in the long run.

In other words, casino operators should consider a responsible gambling strategy as an important business activity because this strategy provides visitors with a positive image and minimizes social costs in the long run. Therefore, casino operators’ responsible gambling strategies not only help them build positive relationships between casino companies and casino visitors but also provide an effective marketing tool for differentiating them from competitors. A responsible gambling strategy should be continuously expanded as an important long-term business activity to enhance casino visitors’ positive images of casino companies and their behavioral intentions to gamble. This strategy will contribute to minimizing adverse social impacts, such as problem gambling, in the long run. Casino operators should promote materials associated with a responsible gambling strategy to casino visitors, so that they can learn about this information.

This study has some limitations that may be addressed in future studies. First of all, the results of the current study may not be generalized to other jurisdictions because data from this study were collected from visitors at Kangwon Land Casino, which is the sole casino for domestic Korean customers. Therefore, additional research using the EMGB is recommended to generalize the findings from this study to those of other jurisdictions, although the results of this study were generally consistent with those of previous studies (e.g., Bagozzi and Dholakia 2006; Carrus, Passafaro, and Bonnes 2008; Oh and Hsu 2001; Taylor 2007). Because the international casino industry has expanded rapidly, cross-cultural studies with different geographical locations would also be useful for increasing external validity (C. K. Lee et al. 2010). Second, future researchers may include more important variables not considered in this model when explaining the casino visitors’ intention-formation process. For example, more responsible gambling strategies in the model that would minimize adverse social impacts resulting from gambling activities may include information on self-exclusion and self-limit programs as well as help lines, clocks in the casinos, and decreased access to ATMs.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Hak-Jun Song, PhD, is a full time lecturer in the Department of Hotel & Convention Management, College of Tourism & Fashion at Pai Chai University in Daejeon, Korea. His research includes casino, forecasting tourism demand, estimating economic impact of tourism, and tourist behavior.

Choong-Ki Lee, PhD, is a professor in the College of Hotel and Tourism Management at Kyung Hee University in Seoul, Korea. His areas of research include casino policy, residents’ perception of casino development, tourism demand, economic impacts of tourism, valuation of ecotourism resources, and festival motivations.

William C. Norman, PhD, is a professor in the Department of Parks, Recreation, and Tourism Management at Clemson University. His areas of research include travel behavior and decision making, tourism marketing, sustainable tourism, and community tourism development.

Heesup Han, PhD, is an assistant professor in the Department of Tourism Management at Dong-A University. His research interest includes green hotels, hospitality and tourism marketing, and scale development.
